Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
Give feedback to the Helper's last response.

### Input:
Helper: It sounds like you are really sad and don't know how to move forward.
Seeker: yes I don't know. I want to move on but I can't too many good memories
Helper: I remember looking at pictures and reminiscing after a break-up too. It helped me to take down pictures to not be reminded of the relationship until I was ready.
Seeker: yes its tough. what should I do to move on? any advice?
Helper: I know that you are working hard on understanding and moving forward with your life, just by reaching out and having this conversation!. Apparently allowing yourself some time to grieve can be a good starting point, according to the experts!
Seeker: ok thanks. good advice. any more? I feel like crap
Helper: Set aside time to do things for yourself. Could you find any time to read, exercise, travel, or something else you enjoy?

It's okay to feel this way, and it's a normal part of healing. What helps you feel better when you're going through a hard time?"}

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
Give feedback to the Helper's last response.

### Input:
Seeker: Hi there!
Helper: Hello! How are you doing today?
Seeker: Oh, not too bad - and you?
Helper: I'm doing well. How can I help you today?
Seeker: I'm just getting frustrated with a cousin of mine. I really appreciate her support through stuff like both my parents dying last year, and I'm trying to support her, too... But she'll be set off by completely unpredictable things. I try hard to avoid any possible conflict, but she finds a way to get hurt anyway.
Helper: I can understand why this would be frustrating for you. Its good that you are trying to support her. Have you talked to her about the way you're feeling?
Seeker: We hardly ever talk on the phone, which sometimes would be easier. I just feel like she's so close to losing it all the time, I don't want to seem critical.
Helper: Do you think she is any sort of danger that someone should know about?
Seeker: Only in the sense that she could have a nervous breakdown, or collapse from exhaustion. She's really strong, though.
Helper: That is understandable. Do you think it's to the point where maybe you should say something to her about it? Even if you might sound a bit critical?

Helper: If it helps to reframe the expense, you can try to think of it as an investment in your mental health.

### Instruction:
Give feedback to the Helper's last response.

### Input:
Seeker: That is a good idea. Do you personally recommend anything on how to balance my schedule and still be able to have my time to do other things?
Helper: When I was at college, I usually aimed at 2 hours of studying everyday (+ homework) and I also aimed to have at least 2 hours of leisure time.
Seeker: I see, and how were you able to maintain a healthy lifestyle with enough sleep and healthy eating habits during college?
Helper: I honestly didn't eat very healthy. If you live with your parents, I think a proper nutrition is easier. I usually slept around 7 hours each night. I picked most of my classes on the afternoon, worked out in the mornings.
Seeker: okay i understand, and what do you suggest for when you do poorly on an exam that you studied so hard for, how do you keep yourself from feeling down?
Helper: I would suggest talking to the professor or an academic advisor to explore strategies that could help you improve
Seeker: okay but is it normal to be upset?
Helper: Of course, it is normal to feel upset. However, you should not blame yourself. No one is perfect.

### Instruction:

### Input:
Helper: I see how that could be intensely difficult to deal with. I think your strength is admirable
Seeker: Thank you, but I'm worried about how long my strength can last
Helper: From our communications it seems you are feeling anxious and stressed as well.
Seeker: Do you have any suggestions?
Helper: Yes, I would suggest you find a place where you are comforted and feel safe. You are in a difficult situation and it is clear you need emotional support as well. Do you know of any support groups in your area?
Seeker: I could reach out to my parents. They have supported me the most.
Helper: I think that is a wonderful idea. You deserve to feel safe and supported too.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
Give feedback to the Helper's last response.

### Input:
Seeker: Yes. Well today I had a delivery order. So I went to McDonald's and pick up the order and took it to the right address and after a few hours I notice that the client did not confirm the order.
Helper: I am not knowledgeable in this service industry. Let me understand. You delivered the order, but the customer did not confirm they wanted it.
Seeker: Five minutes later my supervisor called me saying that the client call and reported that he did not received his order. And that's not true at all, I gave him the food. So now i don't know if they going to fired me or let me keep the job
Helper: Oh i understand, that would be annoying. Did you talk to your supervisor about this situation?
Seeker: Of course I did. He told me he going to give me the benefit of the doubt but that is not enough. Im an honest person and this kind of accusation makes me feel very bad
Helper: I understand, but do not feel bad about yourself. You did your work honestly and delivered the food to your customer. Can I suggest something moving forward?
Seeker: Yes. But stuff like that makes me look bad and makes people dont trust me. Sure. That can help. I would appreciate it
Helper: Maybe every time you make a delivery, you can take a picture of it for proof. or maybe you can have a copy of the receipt and have the customer sign it as well.
Seeker: Well. I normally take pictures of every delivery I make but I let this pass and look what happened
Helper: it's okay, it happens to everyone. we are human and we tend to make the smallest mistakes. The important thing is to learn from them. Is there anything else bothering you at work?
Seeker: Yes. It won't happen again for sure. This makes me dont trust people again. Well. This is the first time I ever faced this kind of problem at work
Helper: as long as you believe in yourself to be honest, don't worry about what other people think. Your boss will come to understand you are a honest worker. It is also amazing that you have come such a long way without having other problems. that is great!
Seeker: I know but sometimes one small thing can hurt you and ruined the reputation that you had build for a long time
Helper: Yes, i understand what you are saying. It's really hard to move on from bad experiences, staying positive is important in these situations.
Seeker: Yes. I guess so. You are right. I just going to move on and do my things. Thank you very much for taking your time and encouraging me with your words
Helper: There's no need to thank me! i hope I could make you feel better.
Seeker: Yes you did. God bless you and have a good one
Helper: Yes, you too! have an amazing rest of your day!

### Input:
Helper: It's a vicious cycle isn't it!? What about looking for another profession that does not involve much retraining?
Seeker: I'm too young to retire but I don't know how many more years I can slog on with this career. It used to be pretty good. Now, it just seems the same gray job every day.
Helper: Are you in a financial position where you could take some time off, go travelling perhaps, and renew yourself?
Seeker: I've thought about that. I'd love to travel. I feel an obligation to my patients. I don't want to abandon them. I could pass them to other therapists, maybe temporarily. I don't know how they would feel about that.
Helper: Well, I would hope that they would understand that even therapists have to have a private life. And I am sure they'd prefer you at the peak of your game and not burned out.
Seeker: True. They might wonder how committed I am to them and to the profession if I go away for a while. I've thought about lightening my work load too.
Helper: Yes perhaps you could switch to part time? If you could afford it?
Seeker: Money not really the issue. I just worry that I'll keep burning out, just more slowly. Other therapists go through this as well.
Helper: Somewhere at the top of the chain there must a very weary therapist with no-one to talk to. Though I suppose that is where these bots come in :D

### Input:
Seeker: Yeah, they gave me pills for that but it didn't help me. I know its hard to help me, I just feel better by talking to someone.
Helper: I'm really sorry you weren't able to get relief with medication. I understand that having someone to talk to can be a relief when you feel so anxious. Do you have any close friends or family that you can talk to more often?
Seeker: Yeah I actually have my best friends and every time i feel horrible I talked to them. But sometimes its just difficult cause bringing the same issue over and over can be exhausting for them.
Helper: I'm sure your friend is glad to be able to lend a listening ear. Sometimes we need to hash out our problems more than once to resolve them. Do you like to exercise? It can be a great way to relieve anxiety and exhaust your body so you sleep better.
Seeker: Actually, yes. I do a lot of exercise and that actually helps me sleep a little.
Helper: I'm so glad to hear you have some outlet for your anxiety that helps with your sleep. Keeping your body healthy can be a great start to getting your mind in a more calm space. If you don't mind me asking, do you work a lot of hours outside your home?
Seeker: No, I'm a student and with the pandemic and all that it's virtual but that keeps me busy.
Helper: I see. Being at home alone most of the time, even when you have virtual meetings, may be contributing to your anxiety. Maybe you could meet up with friends in person at a park or other outdoor location. Is that possible?

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
Give feedback to the Helper's last response.

### Input:
Seeker: I am upset about the loss of my best friend's son dying in a car accident
Helper: I'm really sorry to hear that. When did this happen?
Seeker: The accident was Thursday February 25th but he held on until Sunday the 28th. He was only 26 years old
Helper: There's nothing that can prepare you for unexpected tragedies like this. We just have to deal with them as they come.
Seeker: I understand what you are saying but that's the problem. How to deal with such a terrible unexpected loss. I feel helpless because there is nothing I can do to make her feel better.
Helper: It sounds like you're sticking close to your friend, although it doesn't feel like its helping. It's my experience that when someone has experienced a traumatic loss like that, making someone feel better, at least right away, isn't always an option. The most important thing you can do for her is just to be there for her and allow her to feel however she needs to feel right now.
Seeker: She is inconsolable..... and me also being upset is not helping matters either. You are exactly right...it's impossible to help. That is great advice...thank you. I really appreciate you taking the time to listen
Helper: Of course. These things are tough to face on your own, so you did the right thing by reaching out. I know you want to be there for your friend as much as possible, and I think that will help you to move through grief at the same time, but just be mindful to not overextend yourself too much. You have to be there for yourself too.

### Response:{"perfect": true, "goodareas": ["Self-disclosure"]}

### Input:
Helper: Firstly, you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with depression and it's good that you have reached out for help for this.
Seeker: Any suggestions on what to do about it?
Helper: There are many reasons people have depression. It is a recognised medical condition and the good news is that there is help out there. The first step is recognising the problem.
Seeker: Ok well there is definitely a problem.
Helper: Have you spoken to friends and family about this? do they know how much you are struggling with it at the moment?
Seeker: not really I don't want to bother other people with my problems.
Helper: if people care about you then they will be happy to give you the time and listen to how you are feeling at the moment. I think it will be a really good move to speak to family or friends tell them how you are feeling and talk it through this might really help.
